thread.title: Teenager, 18, found shot dead in village pub car park in North Wales - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Teenager, 18, found shot dead in village pub car park in North Wales - Mirror Online

author: Ben Butler
title: Teenager, 18, found shot dead in village pub car park in North Wales - Mirror Online
text:
News Teenager, 18, found shot dead in village pub car park in North Wales Four men have been arrested in connection with the man's death after police were called to the Ship Inn pub in Llanbedrog in the early hours of this morning Share Police were called to the Ship Inn pub shortly after midnight Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A teenager has been found shot dead in the car park of a village pub in North Wales. 
The 18-year-old's body was found in a vehicle in the Ship Inn pub in Llanbedrog, near Pwllheli, in the early hours of this morning. 
The North Wales Daily Post reports emergency services were called just after midnight but by the time paramedics had arrived at the scene, the man had passed away. 
North Wales Police have confirmed that the family of the victim, who is local to the area, have been informed and are being supported by officers. 
Four men have been arrested in connection with the incident. The pub remains closed today (Photo: Google) 
They are set to be interviewed by detectives while forensic examinations are also continuing at the scene. 
The coroner has also been informed and a post-mortem examination will take place in due course. 
Detective Chief Inspector Andrew Williams, North Wales Police, said: “We are keen to speak with anyone who was in the local area last night and who may have seen a number of males in a Land Rover Discovery vehicle at the location.” 
The pub wrote on Twitter that it will remain closed today while investigations continue. 
A post said: "There has been an incident by the pub. The police have closed the road so will are unable to open today. Back open as normal from tomorrow." 
Anyone with information is requested to contact police on 101 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111. Like us on Facebook
